Anonymous Coward 82130981
Because you have forgotten.
Forgiveness
is one of the most profound teachings of Jesus. In the Gospel of Matthew (18:21-22), Peter asked Jesus how often he should forgive someone who sins against him. Jesus replied, "I tell you, not seven times, but seventy-seven times," signifying that forgiveness should be limitless. His teaching emphasized that one should always forgive others, even if they continually make mistakes or cause harm. The parable of the Prodigal Son in Luke (15:11-32) illustrates this point where the father forgives his wayward son upon his repentance and return, emphasizing the unconditional nature of forgiveness.
In terms of
tolerance
, Jesus taught love and acceptance for all, even those who were shunned by society. In the story of the Good Samaritan (Luke 10:25-37), a man left for dead on the roadside is ignored by a priest and a Levite, but a Samaritan, a figure despised by the J ish people at the time, stops to help him. This parable taught that one's neighbor is not only those who are similar to oneself but everyone, including those who are different or even despised. It highlights the importance of compassion, tolerance, and empathy towards all beings.
As for
humility
, Jesus himself was the embodiment of this virtue. He was born in a humble manger and lived a simple life. In Matthew (20:25-28), Jesus taught that "whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant". He also said, "The Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve." This served to emphasize that greatness comes from humbly serving others rather than seeking personal glory. Jesus' washing of his disciples' feet, as described in John (13:1-17), is a powerful symbol of humility. Despite being their master and teacher, Jesus assumed the role of a servant to teach the virtue of humility.
